pros: A renowned leading research university with terrific faculty. Exciting research. Best Engineering and CS in the world imho, but almost anyone would say top five at least. Large. Set in the middle of twin towns with great food, drink, culture, street life, etc. Great schools and very low cost of living (especially real estate). Extremely international student body and faculty.
cons: Too hard to get to Chicago; we need a bullet train, or at least an Acela. Although airport is very convenient, it has too few flights; frustrating. The Illinois regional state universities are weak or weakening which will create problems if the state puts pressure on UIUC to be more vocationally oriented or more focused on Illinois resident undergraduates. The regionals need to be strengthened so that this doesn't happen.

-changes to the 403b funds from targeted funds to index funds at end of 2021 damaged 403b savings portfolios
-expensove parking

cons: You usually have to change positions to get a raise/promotion so that means that people move positions very frequently. job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Albuquerque, NM
pros: The Graduate Employee Union (GEO) is one o the first and best in the US. Advocates and legislators in Illinois are working to recognize research assistants (RAs) as workers so that they, too, can be represented by the union. My number one recommendation for graduate students at UIUC, even those in STEM and RAs, is to get involved with GEO. They will help you when the administration fails to.
cons: Because graduate students are in a tenuous position as sometime-students, sometimes-employees, the university is ill-equipped to protect students from, for instance, harassment, poor management, and other employment complaints. In the instance I experienced, the university resisted every effort to help graduate students in need, up to the vice president level.

job_title: Engineering IT Student Consultant in Champaign, IL
pros:
My review is for my position as a Student IT Consultant. Tech Support.

1. After the first few weeks, once you get the hang of things, it's really simple for anyone interested in computers and networks.
2. Most problems that we were required to help with were solvable.
3. The full time guys (the grown ups) usually could handle any problem thrown at them and were really helpful.
cons:
My review is for my position as a Student IT Consultant. Tech Support.

1. It's just soooo boring. Especially if you have the morning shift. No one stops by and as you're sitting at the helpdesk, even listening to your iPod is out of question.
2. The work environment is just so messy. Leave a bunch of IT guys together and see the place turn into filth in a day. It's small, cramped, depressing.
3. The pay is horrible. Any other place you'd be payed about twice as much, but the very broke University exploits students who can't work off campus due to restrictions (Internationals) by paying minimum wage. My friend makes three times as much being a waitress.
4. For me and many other students, this was our first form of employment. It does NOT make you look forward to life after college. There are no opportunities for learning, improvement, growth, or networking. It feels like you'll be stuck in that little ex-broom closet forever.

review_title: Good place to work in the C-U area
pros: Great work/life balance, intellectually stimulating, good opportunities for training and learning, excellent amount of vacation time, and good benefits.  I also value the University's education and research mission.  I've been lucky enough to work with good people, so that's helped quite a bit.  Long-term, I don't know if higher ed is for me.
cons: Since it's a public institution, it's filled with bureaucracy and rules that lack common sense.  Leadership also seems to  care more about flash than substance.  For example, instead of trying to improve the quality of education, reduce class sizes, and improve the student/faculty experience, they are more concerned with starting needless projects and programs to make themselves feel like they are doing something important.  They also love to change the names of Departments and Colleges, and call that leadership.  If you work with students, you'll encounter some great ones, but you'll also encounter many rude, entitled ones and others that probably should be flunked out. However, we don't flunk them out because we care more about retention statistics than producing quality alumni.

review_title: small, low-stress, but low budget as well
pros:
Staff perspective: The College of Education is small, so projects and tasks appear easier and more manageable.  Fewer people to work with.  Less politics.  And the education environment is one that attracts people who want to help others, so most people are friendly.

It appears to me that the faculty rule.  What they want, they get, and there are really no incentives for faculty to follow any policies so they don't bother.  They bring in the students who bring in the money so as long as the faculty continue to publish, they are king.
cons: The college has very little money, so if you are faculty getting good grants, or staff working on a federal grant, you can stick around.  If you are essential to business operations you are also generally safe.  But the lack of money hits hard with slight organizational changes and odd staff positions and one-off project personnel to be filled here and there.  Make yourself a necessary piece of the system or you may not last here.

review_title: Being a graduate research assistant at the UIUC will open doors to new opportunities for the rest of your career.
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant In the College of Engineering in Urbana, IL
pros: Let me be clear, I am a graduate research assistant at the University in the department of Mechanical Engineering. The best reason to work (and go to school) at UIUC is to astronomically develop your professional career without having to pay for it. The compensation is not large- it may be difficult to swallow for someone already in the workforce, but the exposure to the people and projects that will shape the future will be incredible experience for the rest of your career.
cons: The hours that a research assistant must put in do not match the compensation if you only consider the pay. You must also consider that tuition is paid, and having a graduate degree will vastly improve your pay scale and opportunities for the rest of your life. There can sometimes be a lack of direction and recognition for work, which is an intrinsic issue of conducting research. Often a new discovery that you've spent many hours on turns out to be not actually useful, or may not work at all. The plus side here is that you are not penalized for this. It's the nature of the business!

review_title: Graduate school is what you make of it
pros:
Living in central Illinois is quite boring, but at least it is inexpensive to live here.  As a graduate student, I was able to purchase a house, which means when I leave I can potentially make some money off it it, rather than just throwing all my stipend out of the window to an apartment complex.  

In terms of working, it really all depends on your department and your boss ... I got along well with my boss, but others certainly have problems.  Most of the people here seem to like graduate school enough to stay and complete their PhD.
cons: Like I said above, you are in central Illinois ... so it is flat, boring, and there is nothing to do.  All of the departments say that "you are within driving distance of Indianapolis, St. Louis, and Chicago" ... but going to each of those places is a full day trip (2, 3, and 2.5 hour drive each way, respectively).  Plus, what could you possibly find to do in Indianapolis??? The most popular activity here, outside of working, is going to bars, restaurants, et cetera.  There really aren't many other activities to do around here, even outdoor / extracurricular activities.

job_title: Graduate Teaching and Research Assistant in Urbana, IL
pros: Excellent professional work environment, wonderful chances for advancement, amazing benefit packages and time off, real support amount the staff for continued pursuit of higher education (as an employee your classes are free).
cons: It is a huge campus so you are a very small cog in the machine.  It is hard to get to know people in other areas of campus.  Also, sometimes word comes down from on high and it isn't as clearly thought out as one would like.

review_title: Good place to be a graduate teaching assistant (at least in the Poli Sci department)
job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Urbana, IL
pros: The Ph.D. program in Political Science offers four guaranteed years of departmental funding, with the possibility of further funding beyond that (which I didn't use, because of external support). Basically, I received $16000 a year to lead three discussion sections per semester. It doesn't seem like a lot of money, but if you look at it on a per-hour basis (I worked less than 20 hours/week on average) it's quite good. Plus, the cost of living is pretty cheap. Pretty happy overall with the quality of work - students are good for the most part, university/departmental administrators generally know what they're doing.
cons: You don't always get a lot of time to coordinate with the professor teaching the course, which can lead to confusion and dissatisfaction among students. Taught an online summer course and got almost no instruction on how to teach an online course - I feel like it wasn't a great experience for either myself or the students. There were also IT issues with the online course. Boring area to live in.

review_title: Lots of career development available, especially for self-starters
pros: There are many career opportunities for those working at the Urbana campus. I know a number of happy people in information technology departments and central IT on campus. Overall the IT community is fairly strong compared to the community or lack of it, at our peer institutions. You have good work-life balance overall. Most people go home at a reasonable hour each night, and working weekends is not the norm. You can start your IT career in one department and move to another (or move to central IT) if you need variety or need to develop new skills.
cons: The declining financial support from the state of Illinois is troubling. Many of my coworkers have observed there are quite a few overpaid administrators here who make 150k+ yearly. Many of these well-paid administrators appear to be risk-averse and prefer maintaining the status quo over pushing for innovation.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Champaign, IL
pros: The university has an outstanding array of resources and technology available to its students and faculty. One of the greatest resources is in fact, the culture of collaborations and innovation present throughout the campus. As a student researcher, it is possible to engage just about anyone on campus, regardless of departmental affiliation. Any idea you come up with, any faculty members you'd like to work with, and any instrument time you'd like to take advantage of are yours for the asking - everyone is incredibly excited about the great research that takes place here.
cons: The administrative overhead present here is the institution's greatest flaw. Despite the resources and interest of faculty, it can frequently take weeks to months to sort through the administrative hurdles that may be present to introduce new pathogens, procedures, or equipment to labs or cleanrooms.

pros: Great benefits if you are a grad student. Can't beat free tuition. And the pay is a lot higher than what most private schools pay their assistants. I know someone who is a teaching assistant at Northwestern and he gets squat for pay. And his insurance really sucks. Another thing that is pretty nice about Champaign is that it is pretty inexpensive to live down there, so even if you aren't making as much as you would be in Chicago, you're still able to save the same amount of money because housing is so cheap. And the bus system is completely free for students!
cons: Having to be in Champaign sucks. It sucks a lot. Why couldn't the University be in Chicago?

review_title: Great campus for academic work; but marred by bureaucracy
pros: Academic professionals are granted significant autonomy at UIUC.  Working hours can be flexible.  General atmosphere is relaxed in most departments.  UIUC is a diverse campus, with top-ranked departments.  Urbana-Champaign has a growing arts, social dance and entertainment scene.   We have the shortest average commute in the US.
cons: A dense forest of bureaucracy surrounds you at UIUC.  Learning to navigate it is the key to survival. UIUC, being a state university, is undergoing fiscal challenges that could have a negative impact on many AP positions.  Parking on campus is scarce; but the bus system helps.  Illinois state employees pay into the SURS retirement system.  (Some consider this a benefit.)

job_title: Sales Associate (Sales Girl) in Urbana, IL
pros: I absolutely loved my manager and assistant manager. Although Chuck might come off as intimidating at first he was such a great leader and although monotone he is quite the funny man. Ben the assistant manager is such a great leader. Always ready to lend a helping hand. They both never let their titles get in the way of helping others and they always had constructive criticism without putting us down or yelling when mistakes were made.
cons: I can't really say anything was a con other than minimum wage and never getting raises...getting dirty and some awful smells from time to time when cleaning. And freezing your butt off from time to time while pulling orders and stocking the freezer. Other than that the people were wonderful to work with and the meat was THE BEST at such a great price.

review_title: Hourly Paid Graduate Position easily fit my life as a student
job_title: Hourly Paid Graduate Assistant in Urbana, IL
pros: The University of Illinois, Urbana-Champaign is a great employer because it is steady.  I was always paid promptly.  Because I was reporting to a person I consider a mentor who I saw on a daily basis, I felt very supported in my role while given the freedom to take initiative.  I cannot speak for other's supervisor relationships.  I found the office staff to be consistently knowledgeable, helpful, and polite.
cons: I never had any significant problems at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign.  I wished the graduate student positions paid more.  I only worked about 10 hours a week, but my goal was mainly to cover books and groceries.  For students who work as full time TAs/GAs I know they have trouble covering cost of living.  Reimbursements also take a long time, but, honestly, that I have found that to be true in any large organization.

pros:
You make your own hours, thats the biggest thing. You address support tickets on your own time, so you can make it work around your class schedule. Your work is rewarded with 3 awards given out at each semester as well as wage raises. I have recieved over a $1.00 raise each semester I have worked here.

Also, once you prove yourself, you are given a unit assignment when you work with a particular department of the university on a regular basis. Unit assignments differ, but they offer fantastic experience as a systems administrator. I work at my unit assignment 12 hours a week and it is a dream job for a college student.
cons: There are bi-weekly meetings you have to attend which are largely pointless, but you get paid for attending so its not all bad.

review_title: Computer Science department has some great research, picking your adviser can make a pick difference
pros: Well-recognized computer science department.  A wide variety of research activity available, unlike what you might find at smaller schools.  The professors are well-funded, so there are lots of assistantship opportunities.
cons: There seemed to be a lack of collaborative research in the computer science department relative to other schools.  While not true of all professors, overall there was a feeling that the professors did not prepare their PhD students to compete on the job market as well as other top tier schools.  Look at a professor's track record of placing their PhDs and decide if that's about where you'd like to be where you graduate.

pros: My coworkers were all pretty interesting people and there was a strong sense of camaraderie within departments. The University does a lot of different things so there are quite a few opportunities to learn new technologies and try new things, as long as you are interested in staying in IT.
cons:
The internal politics are distracting and make it harder to get real work done. I found that this employer killed my enthusiasm fairly quickly once I realized most of the managers only paid lip service to your ideas. Also, there was always far more work than time. Crisis mode was pretty constant.

If you join as an hourly worker, figure out how to get salaried as soon as possible. Benefits for hourly workers are pretty much non-existent.

review_title: A decent place to work in a great city
pros: UIUC is a hub for innovation in the middle of nowhere Midwest; the communities of Champaign and Urbana are fantastic, and Chicago is 2 hours away (St. Louis 2.5 hours away). UIUC varies greatly by department. Mine had great people but lots of leadership dysfunction -- something I think many academic departments run into because most "brilliant" professors aren't automatically good administrators.
cons: Did not like that they kept increasing lecture classes by HUNDREDS over the years. Too many students meant TAs were just grade-granting machines and faculty where overwhelmed. Reported sexual harassment to HR, was not taken seriously, even after I followed up several times.

job_title: Office Support Specialist in Champaign, IL
pros:
Coworkers are great - very dependent on department
Casual to casual business attire makes it great for extremely hot/cold days
Healthcare benefits are good - could be better
The university does not depend on state funds too much, was able to avoid massive layoffs
Being in the union means some protection and greater consistency in job tasks
cons:
Poor parental leave
Rules can be draconian
Raises based on university administration 
Change can be slow; despite evidence to that things could be improved quickly
Being in the union can also mean being held back despite being more than qualified for a promotion - unable to skip positions even if you are already doing those tasks or beyond.

pros:
Most units are autonomous, so you can make the job what you would like it to be.  Depending on the department you work for, training opportunities can be extensive, or nonexistent.  For being a large campus, the IT community is a fairly close-knit one, and allows you to connect with colleagues should you wish it.

Vacation and sick time benefits are some of the best.  If you enjoy good work-life balance, this is the place to be.
cons: Small towns are not everybody's cup of tea.  Salaries are accordingly low to match the low cost of living.  State budget issues always make you wonder if your raise will cover cost of living increases (it won't).  Furlough days have happened in recent memory, so be prepared.

review_title: UIUC not the worst, not the best
pros: Good salaries, above average. Good benefits although state is in trouble; lots of days off. Decent city and people to work with. Commute is usually not more 10-15 mins. Affordable housing and cost of living. Great job security. Research time (but only 10%).  Room for interdepartmental collaboration. Smart driven staff. Have autonomy with job.
cons: No pay raises for Professional Associates. Class-ist system, so only faculty matter when voting and most opinions. Not much room for growth. Constant budgetary concerns. People stay to  long and are bitter; makes doing your job difficult.  Paid monthly. No spousal tuition waiver;  only 50% off for child tuition.  Everyone is overworked with tightening of belts. Do not seem to matter to upper management. Change moves at a glacial pace; so technology, policies, hiring and other things could be streamlined and improved. Constant stress and pressure.

review_title: Great town to live in, nice culture
pros: I enjoyed working in an innovative environment where thinking differently was embraced. Nice benefits for academic professionals. Champaign is a great community with a lot going on.
cons: Low pay for non-tenure track staff and raises are far and few between. Not much opportunity for promotions. The atmosphere of a corrupt state government has placed a lot of restrictions on the university as far as hiring. It takes a long time to get through the process of hiring, like nearly a year, and the restrictions on what is allowed and not allowed makes it difficult to vet job candidates. Also, the weather in that area can be quite severe.

review_title: Large school, lots of resources, specific student type!
job_title: Resident Hall Director in Urbana, IL
pros:
+ lots of resources 
+ become a specialist in the area you work 
+ great professional development opportunities 
+ multiple areas of campus to work with, learn from, transfer departments
cons:

-student population is extremely hard working, determined, and sometimes overwhelming

- many procedures are set in stone and leadership is not quick to make changes

review_title: Not the best review to read
pros:
Champaign is a good place to live.  It is a great campus town.

The University is a fantastic research institution.  If you are in interested in working in Engineering or related fields, this is definitely one of the best places you could work.  The buildings are stunning, as is the work.  Other departments are also good, but are not always as well funded.

The University has a great college atmosphere, one of the best places to study.  It has that special mix of geniuses of our time as well as your average person as it is a state school.  You must visit if you're interested.
cons: Champaign is a very small town.  If you aren't a student, there isn't much to do.

review_title: World-Class Research University with Some Deep Problems Nevertheless
pros: Brilliant colleagues.  Freedom to create and teach courses in one's expertise.  Good opportunities for 1-2 semesters released from teaching to pursue research and writing.  User-friendly airport nearby.  Good performing arts centers with four stages.  Several good restaurants and coffee shops. Visiting researchers from around the world appearing regularly for talks, seminars, conferences.
cons: Students range from highly motivated/Ivy League-worthy to unmotivated/dubious merit as high school grads.  Racist mascot still casts a long shadow.  Difficult town-gown relations (surrounding community much more politically and socially conservative than campus community).  Local airport only has direct flights on American Airlines to Chicago and Detroit--therefore, most trips require at least one layover in one of these cities.

review_title: Financially squeezed by corrupt Chicago politicians
job_title: Information Technology Specialist in Urbana, IL
pros: Very nice benefit package when you are hired but the state is trying to shave them to save money.  Lots of school spirit & strong traditions.  Pretty campus.
cons: Always a scandal - Presidents come & go quickly, corrupt admissions, Department Director is deemed a felon, you name it......   Dire financial state of Illinois puts University in jeopardy.  Pensions are under siege, furloughs, no new hires lead to chronic under staffing.  Academic jobs being reclassified as Civil Service.  Location in the flat cornfields in the middle of nowhere..  Bitterly cold winters.  I had very poor support from college level but that may have been specific to the college & not university wide.

review_title: The best 12 years of my life were at the University of Illinois, Urbana-Champaign
job_title: Senior Assistant Director in Champaign, IL
pros: While at U of I I grew as a person and as a professional. I was given responsibility and autonomy in one of the best Career Centers in the nation. My colleagues were excellent professionals who I enjoyed working with. My supervisors became mentors who helped me develop as a professional.
cons: Champaign-Urbana is a nice college community.  As I approached age 50 I needed to live in a larger urban area that had social options more for my demographic.

job_title: Chemistry Teaching Assistant in Urbana, IL
pros: Looks great on a resume, you get to help some great kids, you are always paid for 10 hours a week even though you are only teaching for about 5 of them -- they try to take grading time into account
cons: Being a TA takes a lot of time. I had to create my own worksheets and grading takes a crazy amount of time. I also don't like that the "office hours" are in the Chemistry Learning Center where all of the chemistry students in the entire university come to ask questions because they are usually asking TAs that do not teach the class they're asking about.

job_title: Customer Service Assistant in Champaign, IL
pros: The work environment is friendly and casual and there are excellent opportunities for advancement. The staff is put to good use and it is very easy to manage class and work load because you are able to choose how many hours you wish to work during the week. The facilities are outstanding and well-maintained, so it is easy to enforce membership and safety policies to patrons.
cons: Can be understaffed in certain departments at times. The job is not very challenging or social as a Facility Assistant but once you are able to advance to Customer Service Assistant or Facility Manager, the community becomes much closer and more enjoyable.

review_title: A good university that handles student employment well.
pros: I worked as a research assistant for the university - not a glamorous job, but everything was handled well by HR and I had a decent time there working for a professor. I never got the impression that they were unprofessional or untimely.
cons: Obviously, it's not great pay, but this is coming from a research assistant. It was definitely nice to mention on my resume, but not exactly a huge career boost, either.

review_title: A lot of research freedom, but low pay, and poorly managed.
job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in Champaign, IL
pros: You can work in a wide variety of basic research labs and pursue a wide range of research.  Many of your fellow researchers will be top notch, and well respected in their fields.
cons: The pay for a highly educated scientist is ridiculously low, as it is in all of academia, and the labs are run by scientists, not managers, so a lot of the equipment falls apart, or doesn't have any one who knows how to use it.  A lot of time is wasted on issues like that.

job_title: Undergraduate Teaching Assistant in Urbana, IL
pros: Convenient to work for the University while taking classes. The culture is great - everyone really cares about what they are doing. It's a pretty easy job if you know what you're doing, and there are plenty of opportunities to do more or less. Compensation is fine considering the job, and the hours are flexible.
cons: Honestly, there are no significant cons. Obviously, there isn't opportunity to "advance," but you can do more creative work if you want. The flexibility in the job really makes up for any potential cons.

review_title: Great graduate student academic environment in the physics department
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Urbana, IL
pros: The faculty is excellent, and the physics research is top-notch.  Collaboration between theory and experimental groups is excellent as well, which makes for a friendlier working environment in the department as a whole.  A wide range of labs for students.  Physics grad students aren't paid very well, but the cost of living is so low in Urbana-Champaign that it's very manageable.
cons: Compared to other physics departments and even other physical sciences departments at UIUC, the department is a little less structured, which is great for motivated students but can allow others to meander through without much oversight, leading to longer PhD's.  The surrounding town is also small, but at least Chicago is only two hours away.

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in Urbana, IL
pros: Flagship state university campus with diverse laboratory and computing resources and dedicated faculty. Impressive emphasis on interdisciplinary research through formalized institutions on campus. Also the cost of living in a Midwest college town is way lower than I was used to on the East Coast. Champaign-Urbana is a surprisingly decent place to live; nice downtown restaurants and bars, reasonable infrastructure, and some pretty residential neighborhoods.
cons: The State of Illinois is a perpetual financial nightmare and the university system suffers the consequences in the form of erratic funding. All state pension systems are chronically underfunded so even though the retirement benefits from SURS look really good, they may not actually exist when you need. If flat terrain and corn/soybeans make you uncomfortable, this area isn't for you.

review_title: Full of opportunities, focus on independence, and facilitates healthy competition.
pros: You can be whoever you want - you can have fun, study hard, be connected, and learn many things outside of your curriculum. The material is tough, but if you come out of it alive, you'll be a better person.
cons: Competition can also be a con here in terms that some people take it to an unhealthy level. The location is nice except for the sketchy neighborhood bordering the NW campus area as there have been many crime alerts.

review_title: This school offers great jobs For its students  and it offers flexible hours that coincide  with class schedules
pros: location location location. Everything is a bus ride away so I don't have to worry about being absurdly  late. I really like the work environment  because everyone is a student it is really chill.
cons: It's hard to get a job that is not working with the dinning halll. And I guess the dinning hall is a great option for work it's just the environment  seems a bit depressive.

review_title: Nice culture, decent city, great math department
pros: I enjoyed my job, and the pepple I worked with. The math department, unlike some departments, has a positive environment for its employees. I also worked IT for the LAS department, and it was OK.  If you work in a non-administrative position, the atmosphere is good.
cons: As with any public institution, it alway feels as if the University is deteriorating. Often times there is too much work and not enough time. And the pay is not stellar, but you can consistently make as much or more than your peers in other fields.

review_title: My experience working for this company was wonderful, full of exciting opportunities and possibilities.
job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Champaign, IL
pros: Daily interacting with intelligent, curious, youthful people makes one feel the same way.  I have made many friends, in many different areas, because we are all here to learn.
cons: One may find themselves carried away by the fun, fantastical environment, and just float along.  Before they know it, eight years have passed and they have not yet graduated.  Enjoy yourself but grab the brass ring!

review_title: Great place for Engineering grad students, if you can ignore the bureaucracy.
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Urbana, IL
pros: The department has a world-class reputation that is well-deserved. At the same time, it is very supportive, often going out of their way to help graduate students. Some amenities are really good for a state university, like the gym.
cons: Although the department is great to its students, the university administration seems to strive in the opposite direction. Loads of rules and technicalities to restrict tuition waivers and stipends for graduate students. I suppose that's a result of the tightened state budget, but it's too bad grad students are punished for it.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Champaign, IL
pros: Incredible opportunities for collaborations across top rated departments. Very supporting, nurturing environment for graduate students in the beginning of the program. You can take courses from different departments, for instance, in addition to your major PhD program in Econ you can complete master in Statistics or Mathematics.
cons: Top rated departments are very demanding to the quality of research. It is not a con in general, but the droprate 40% on some departments (after 5 years) should be announced in the very beginning of the program.

review_title: Very rewarding and eye opening job
pros: Get to work with a wonderful and very diverse group of people. Meet with new and International Students who you get to help with their way around Campus and Housing. You process and process information regarding staff and student's on Computer, a lot of office duties and customer service care to the students.
cons: Sometimes chances are you end up with a graveyard shift because the Front Desk is opened 24/7, and you also required to work one holiday break (Christmas, Thanksgiving, New year, Spring Break)

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Urbana, IL
pros: The research experience I get in my department is phenomenal. The surroundings are great. For the cost of living in the area, the salary is sufficient if you're single. Pretty good dental and health for the price.
cons: No bonuses and little opportunity for raises (there's one after passing your prelim in my department).

job_title: Microbiology Preparatory Lab Staff in Urbana, IL
pros: You can work in the microbiology prep labs part time during school and then there is a possibility for full time over the summer, so it's an awesome opportunity that can be flexible for your schedule. You can also be promoted to a manager in your time there because as older students graduate, younger students need to step up. So, there is an upward career path that looks great on a resume!
cons: There is a commitment that you need to honor because you are helping run courses, so as flexible as the management is with your schedule, you have  reciprocate and be able to take a few shifts proctoring exams from 7-10 pm.

review_title: Employment experience varies greatly by department
pros: Flexible hours, great vacation/sick leave i.e. while my Champaign-Urbana colleagues working in science/engineering/IT outside the university (in industry) typically earned higher salaries than me, I had about 3-4 times as much time off annually as them. Trade offs.
cons: Moderate pay. Can be difficult to advance depending on dept., most advancements require moving depts., buildings, starting over in new setting with new people, often this is necessary for even an incremental advancement.

review_title: A prestigious land grant university services satellite offices in a manner consistent with on-campus support.
pros:
A wealth of knowledge lies at your disposal.

Two categories of employment, Academic Professionals and Civil Service, offer great benefits in the form of sick and vacation time, as well as tuition reimbursement, medical, dental, eye care and retirement packages.

Employees are friendly and open to suggestion and hard work.
cons: Campus employment benefits do not extend particularly far outside of the Urbana-Champaign area, and a culture of incuriosity surrounds off-campus employment.

job_title: Undergraduate Research Assistant in Urbana, IL
pros: Friendly staff, very helpful, lots of resources available, excellent libraries. I enjoyed working in a research laboratory for biomechanics and getting to work with all types of people and subjects.
cons: The location of Champaign-Urbana is quite far from the nearest city, so often we would have to travel a lot for conferences and meetings with other clients. It was also hard to find a large subject pool meeting our requirements in such a small area.

review_title: Economics Grad School: hard by satisfying
pros:
You learn a lot, especially in your first year.  There's good camaraderie within the department.  Overall, the work is satisfying.

The professors are very good at helping their students do work.
cons:
The program is difficult, there are hard-quals and long hours.  Five years is a long time to be on a grad student stipend.

It's possible to 'get lost' in the department and end up spending a lot of time teaching without making much progress towards graduation.

People who are thinking of a PhD in Economics should look into Finance and Accounting programs, too.  They do similar research, take many of the same classes, but get paid more.

review_title: Facilities & Services is a great division to work in
pros: F&S is a fantastic environment and group of people to work with - everyone is in this together, collaborative, and willing to have fun at work while still working hard.  The leadership (and all the employees) are dedicated to a great "corporate" culture, and always have potlucks, parties, and fundraising events for charity.  There's no sense of hierarchy here, really, and it makes getting work done that much more enjoyable.
cons: Since there are such defined roles, the chance to be promoted internally is a challenge.  F&S loses some good people to other opportunities in other UIUC departments because of this.

review_title: This is a review of UIUC
pros: There are some good things about working here, some not so good. If one enjoys the good things, the bad things may not be so bad. All in all it is OK. Working in general is good, and one should be happy to be working, regardless of the type of work or location. This place is no exception.
cons: The downsides are typical of this kind of work environment. One can certainly expect these things to be a factor when coming to work here. If one does not expect these things, then it will be more difficult to deal with them as they inevitably arise. So do your research.

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in Urbana, IL
pros: I have a great advisor who is extremely supportive without being overbearing.  I know there are many highly regarded faculty on campus.  I have recieved great support on my own personal research.  Also, I would say that I have met many interesting people doing interesting things in other departments.  Great place for engineering/physical sciences.  Great post-doc experience.
cons: I don't have any real cons.  I'm sure there is somebody somewhere on campus doing something stupid in management, but I don't really pay attention to the politics.  If you want to come here and do research, it's a great place.

review_title: Experience as an Undergraduate Researcher at the U of I
pros: Phenomenal learning opportunity from experienced graduate students and well-accomplished yet down-to-earth professors. Also, significant resources are available via the university investments in a ton of research databases which provides students with access to many publications.
cons: Lack of name recognition compared to other well-known universities. Additionally, research may be viewed as a lesser alternative compared to an internship, eventhough the exposure and consequential benefit of it may be much greater to the student.

pros: I LOVED teaching LAS 100. LAS 100 is a semester long orientation course for freshman. You have flexibility and creativity with the class, and can help freshman get the inside scoop on the campus resources.  A perfect way to try out teaching, and it is a great program to talk about in interviews post graduation!
cons: Takes a lot of time to develop course materials... be prepared for that.  If you don't prepare your lesson plan, everyone knows. The pay is not too high for the amount of work put in.

review_title: It was challenging, but rewarding and even enjoyable when you worked with the right people.
job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Champaign, IL
pros:
Wide variety of opportunities both work related and interpersonal.
Campus provides ample space to work with and when needed take a walk to clear your head or continue your work in your mind.
cons:
Depending on the task at hand collaboration on non-core objectives might be difficult. 
Outside of the school and the student related activities things can be limited.

pros: A nice midsize campustown, with very short commutes and almost no rush hour traffic. A great place to raise kids.
cons: Winters can be pretty cold and snowy sometimes, and they have been more frequently so in the recent years. Air travel always requires a hop to chicago or a drive to Indianapolis or chicago.

job_title: EWS Lab Consultant in Urbana, IL
pros: The job does not require much work and its very relaxed. Pay is minimum at first but getting raises is not difficult and the raises are nice. Also you are independent with no one watching you.
cons: I can't really think of any. Conflicts with school schedule sometimes, but since you are allowed to sub any shift you want as long as you give notice and you sign up for your own schedule, it's really not bothersome.

pros: UIUC sas a large library where you can get almost all the reference you want. UIUC also has very strong engineer programs. Professors are responsible for the students and they are glad to spend time with their students talking about research or non-research topics in-class and out-class.
cons: The geographic location is not close to metropolitan areas, which is OK for academia workers but not advantageous for industry-oriented individuals

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Urbana, IL
pros:
-The University of Illinois has a serious and disciplined student environment, good communication, and the possibility of joining other projects which allow you to meet other professionals in your field. 
-Friendly and very professional workers, available to help
-Diversity
-Getting the work done was more important than staying in the office from 9 to 5, so I could set my work-life balance
-Lots of information and guidance for career opportunities
cons:
-Low salary
-Slow administration
-Poor management. Manager failed to clarify the instructions from the beginning, something that brought severe misunderstandings that could have been avoided.

review_title: Reasonable Avancement, but lacking in personnel issues
pros: There are very good opportunities, in most cases, to enrich your skills and branch out to new skills.  Most people are good.
cons: Personnel issues are not handled well at all., especially for those in Bargaining Units. Toxic atmospheres are created that cause stress and work issues.  Raises are automatic for bargaining unit employees but those who are exempt are at the mercy of whether or not their supervisor likes them.

job_title: Research Assistant In Computer Science in Urbana, IL
pros: There's a lot going on intellectually and culturally, especially given it's in a smaller city.  Most people are nice and down-to-earth.
cons: Not the best place to meet folks in their late 20s.  My advisor was very vague and hands-off, which lead me to spend a lot of time, not do a lot of publications, and generally feel that my research was pointless.

review_title: Too big to care about its students
job_title: Ph D Graduate Student in Champaign, IL
pros: Ranked in top 5, which means companies love the students.
cons: They track what their students write online about them or the school in general. Make sure you post something nice, or else you're called in for a face to face Q&A. It's ridiculous the amount of resources they actually spend on this, when they could spend that to address the problems raised by students on their online posts.

pros: A lot of resources from various engineering departments.
cons: Some PhD advisors are not professionally trained or guided to work with Research Assistants (PhD students). They intend or didn't really intend to abuse Research Assistants and produce little meaningful research results. The administration does not pay attention to the PhD students and they didn't regulate/guide the phd advisors enough. Some young assistant professors are too narrow minded and short-sighted. And lack professionality and morality.

pros:
-Very enjoyable people to work with. Everyone seems to at least moderately like their job. Very friendly and sociable to work with.
-Administration is very understanding and tries to work with your schedule, whether you are a student at the near by university or not. 
-The main building is very cool with lots of display cases detailing wildlife and other natural history of Illinois
cons:
-The scientists and researchers can sometimes be difficult to work with because they are so focused on their specific subject of research. 
-The main building is isolated off campus and can be a bother to find

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in Urbana, IL
pros: The pay is comparable with other universities ~45-50 K and the living expenses are really low. Therefore, your money can go a long way. The environment is great, a lot of resources are available across campus not only in your department or research group. Also, there are workshops with the postdocotral affairs in the grad college and also events to meet other postdocs from other departments.  Benefits are ok. There's health insurance, eye vision, dental, retirement, and life insurance.
cons: If you are a foreign national you have to meet a minimum presence in the USA in order to qualify for benefits.

review_title: I have been working at this University as a Postdoc for 5 years.
job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in Champaign, IL
pros: U of I is a research-intensive university and comprises 17 colleges covering almost all the programs you can think of. So pretty much you can find the program you like to study here. The campus is very diverse with almost half population from foreign countries. It's pretty easy to get accustomed for an international student/staff. Plus, Champaign has one of the best transportation systems in the States.
cons: There is no any interesting place to visit in the Champaign-Urbana area. The weather is horrible in the winter. and usually the spring season is transient.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Urbana, IL
pros: I worked as a graduate employee in a department that valued my skills.   I was given a living wage, excellent opportunity for professional growth, access to healthcare, and the chance to work with mentors who provided good guidance not only about my job, but also about academics and life.
cons: The obstructionist way the university treats its labor unions.  It just goes against the grain.  Also, there is a lot of turmoil at the top of the organization.

pros: The benefits are amazing, especially the vacation and sick leave policy.  The unit I'm in is very flexible to match my scheduling needs -- flex time and working from home are not uncommon in my group.
cons: The unit I'm in is very heavy on managers who talk a lot and seem to accomplish little.  My manager has less education and less expertise than many/most of the employees under him.

review_title: Many excellent opportunities available for students
pros: The University does a really excellent job of providing multiple job options for students. While there isn't much room for advancement during a student's college experience, most offices/departments are often very generous with offering full-time positions to students once they graduate. Employers are also usually very flexible and understanding of finals, midterms etc
cons: Most jobs are administrative and therefore don't necessarily prepare you for anything after graduation aside from to say you held down a job.

pros: Flexible scheduling according to your availability, so you can work between classes or after classes, take shifts, etc. Very good job with acceptable pay as a student going to the university, friendly environment
cons: Have to work late night and odd hours, can disrupt classes or studies. Other than that, there are not much that is bad to say about this job. You get good experience dealing with customers renting the event space.

review_title: Helpful student experience but poorly run
job_title: Student Office Assistant in Champaign, IL
pros: I learned how to manage an office and deal with large data sets for a department at the university. As a student, it helped pay for food and other expenditures.
cons: The university gave me and other student staff no notice of being laid off from budget cuts. Scrambling to find another source of income was stressful and scary when paying for important expenses was the line.

pros: Great personal to work with as well as a great environment. You learn a lot on the job, and get to interact with some of the greatest minds of our time.
cons: You have to be a graduate student to really get paid nicely, and the work load sometimes can be large. Make sure you have enough time for this.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Urbana, IL
pros: Spacious, nice facilities, awesome faculty and smart graduate students. Not much distraction, and you have a very quiet, relaxed life that will help you concentrate on researches.
cons: UIUC is located in a typical "university town", with few connections and little internship opportunities to real industry world. If you wanna go to industry instead of academia after graduation, you need to plan your outreach and networking by yourself by traveling to bigger other places (at least 3 hour drive).

review_title: Great place to be a graduate student if you can find a good fit with a field of study and advisor.
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant  in Urbana, IL
pros: If you are a graduate research assistant in a field where the University is well-respected (EE like me, or others), you will probably have a chance to work on some of the latest technology and most important problems in your field. This is exciting and also prepares you well for your next "real job." Particularly in engineering, the University is respected by employers across the country who have hired proficient graduates in the past. I enjoy the setting, small city with some nice cultural offerings, good transit, good proximity to bigger places, nice downtown area, but affordable cost of living.
cons: If you are looking to live in either a small-town or big-city setting, you will be disappointed as Urbana-Champaign is in between. Upper management is doing ok at steering the University in the direction it needs to go and is certainly keeping it compettitive with other U.S. public as well as private institutions, but sometimes there are some boneheaded people at middle management level. The University is huge enough that as a graduate student here, these are the people who will impact your day-to-day existence, and I have encountered a few who have come into power to run a laboratory and have made things much worse for the users and generally done some stupid things that most everyone else finds frustrating. Since the economic incentives to serve the user/customer and be fiscally responsible are diluted here compared to the private sector, and with the tenure system and certain cultural things here, accountability is low and sometimes it takes quite an effort for these people to be removed. Also, as a graduate student, much definitely depends on what kind of advisor you have. Probably more than anything else.

pros: There are a lot of opportunities for anyone willing to learn. The university is famous for its research funding and it shows. If you have any worthwhile idea, they will provide you with enough support to pursue it. Also, the university has some of the most advanced technologies in the world so you will be learning from some of the best in the profession.
cons: As is the problem with big universities, there are too many people doing the same thing sometimes and you yourself have to be organized in your research otherwise your work might go unrecognized and unaccounted for.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Champaign, IL
pros: Flexible schedule apparently...respected university with good reputation in the industry. Have a close relationship with the industry. Graduates go on to careers as leaders in research, industry, education, and government.
cons: low salary. long time working. Need to work really hard to get what you want to achieve. No holiday, no weekend.

review_title: Faculty don't care about you, link up with Staff Scientist and Post-Docs
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Urbana, IL
pros: World Class Lab facilities with great staff that are very helpful (Fredrick Seitz Materials Laboratory). The people here are very friendly and want you to succeed.
cons: Share facilities means you have to use the same equipment as everyone else. Sometimes researchers dont take care of facility tools which ends up becoming your problem. Faculty members tend to be absent from the day to day operations of a group.

pros: Fantastic reputation, many good researchers and stimulating intellectual environment. Many excellent departments offer many opportunities to engage with the public, and many faculty are open to cross-disciplinary work and collaboration. Library facilities are second to none. Vibrant arts scene - shows at the Krannert Center are world-class and comparatively cheap (not exceeding $40 or so for student tickets for performances like Yo-Yo Ma). Fantastic farmers' market. Great Chinese food (by Midwestern standards).
cons:
The brand name really could be better, if the administration shaped up its act. The university-level administration is grossly incompetent, often bungling up even simple things like billing students correctly for tuition and fees. The assistantships don't cover fees, leading to nasty shocks for new graduate students who have to cough up fees at the start of each semester.

The Chancellor and President often act unilaterally without consultation from the student body (nor from the faculty, apparently) - recent examples of the cancellation of the wind turbine project (funded from student fees!) and the forcible retirement of the Chief Illiniwek icon are just two recent examples that come to mind. Rather than spending money on improving education or buildings (like Lincoln Hall), the administration instead funded the construction of a new (ugly) bell tower, oversaw a >$100m overhaul of the football stadium, and spent hundreds of millions of dollars on implementing the Banner system for administration that does even less than the system it replaced. It really makes students and staff wonder if the administration has its priorities straight. 

This university also has problems keeping their senior faculty - it's as if the university severely underpays them or undervalues them in other ways.

The University also suffers from its distance from any major city (the closest is Chicago at 135 mi away). The winter weather is terrible - it's always windy. The airport is rather pathetic in its limited choice of routes, and is usually so costly to fly out of that it's often cheaper to drive up to Bloomington, IL or the Chicago airports.

review_title: Stimulating University with great benefits, but lack of upward mobility leaves much to be desired
pros: Like most places, the people make this place amazing. Everyone is trying to make the campus a better place and it feels revitalizing to work in an atmosphere like that. The vacation and sick benefits are astounding and I suggest people take advantage of them as no other company offers such amazing time.
cons: There is no upward mobility. It seems like you are locked into your position with your salary and changes are very incremental (to the tune of 1% a year). Although the tuition benefit is great, classes are held during the work day so you must get department consent to miss working time to take classes which they may or may not approve depending on your supervisor. If planning to attain a degree, it may be difficult. Be warned that some online programs are excluded from the tuition benefits as well making it even more difficult. People really like the pension system, but I didn't think it was that great considering that most retiring today are not getting what they were told when they were starting. Also, the pension is in lieu of social security. Although some believe social security is at risk in sustaining, i'm not sure the state pension is in any better place. Either way, I suggest employee's use various methods of retirement savings other than the state pension.

pros:
* Flexible work schedule
* A good place to be if you're trying to see what grad school is like
* Stick around if you need some income + work experience but can't decide on a career yet
* There are lots of projects going at the same time, you can usually find something that interests you
cons:
* No promotion, basically a temporary position
* No benefits/compensation beyond an hourly wage
* You get paid less than a grad student, and you don't get a degree out of it
* Payable hours not guaranteed, you can easily run out of work

job_title: Assistant Professor, Tenure Track in Champaign, IL
pros: Great expertise and resources at the institution for interdisciplinary collaborations. The salary ceiling is pretty high once you reach the rank of full professor. Typically, deserving faculty are offered much more space to conduct research than most public and private universities.
cons: The state is bankrupt, the university gets approximately 40% of its funding from the state, and this creates immeasurable burden on everyone. Be ready to do more for much less. The amount of service work required is also insanely high because of faculty turnover. It's also difficulty to recruit and retain faculty in the Midwest.

review_title: Amazing Benefits. Below average salary. Experience varies greatly for each unit/college.
pros:
- One of the best PTO and sick leave policies in the country--- varies a bit depending on whether Civil Service or Academic Professional position.
- Flexible hours (depending on unit).
- Tuition waiver for University of Illinois System (free higher education!).
- One of the best health insurances.
- Typically low-stress work environment (depending on manager/departmental culture).
- Professional development funds are usually decent and can range from two to four grand depending on unit.
- The best work/life balance that I have seen.
cons:
- Most departments pay below-market salaries for developers.
- As a dev, your work may not translate well to what is expected of you in the private sector, which puts you at a disadvantage if you were to leave.
- Because we depend on the state budget there have been years where no cost-of-living adjustment was given, which essentially translates to having less purchasing power---or effectively a lower salary---than you did the previous year. 
-When there is a cost-of-living adjustment it's usually only 2%, and sometimes double for upper management.
-Some departments are run by entitled faculty, some of which may have tenor and are almost impossible to fire. To say that they can be rude is an understatement, and management is grossly overpaid for a government job, especially in light of the fact that their employees don't get merit-based raises or appropriate cost-of-living adjustments often enough.
-You essentially have to "jump around" departments or get external offers in order to get a fair raise.
-Some departments push devs to work as tech leads or managers without offering title or appropriate pay raise to go with it.  There should be policies at the University-level to address this matter.

review_title: A Review of Graduate Employee Salaries
job_title: Graduate Research/Teaching Assistant in Champaign, IL
pros:
Nice area-- some urban elements, but easy to get away in more rural areas easily. Short drives to St. Louis and Chicago (both 2.5-3 hours), and to hiking trails.

Atmosphere is nice for a large campus-- within a department, you can feel some closeness, then walk out to another part of campus and be completely isolated. 

Cute campus "downtown" area with decent restaurants.

Graduate employees, specifically, have a union that is fairly robust and strong. For most degree programs, there will be financial support and a teaching or research assistantship that will provide a tuition waiver plus stipend.

Here are my offer letter terms:

33% TA + Waiver (stipend was $15,570 for the academic year)

25% GA + Waiver (stipend was $908.94/mo, but taxed)

25% GA + Waiver ($949.83/mo., taxed) 

I also held hourly positions ($20/hr for skilled, $8/hr for unskilled). Note that TA positions are exempt from the tax code, but GA positions tax after the first $5,250. 

Assistantships are great for getting experience-- in fact, my positions were probably what landed me a job before graduation. However, in many departments, competition over them can be fierce. You may want to look outside your home department for a position. 

In addition, you may get an offer for a position with the acceptance notice-- but you may also get accepted without any offer (so you must go find one with a waiver). If you look for the assistantship clearinghouse, you'll find a listing of positions that don't particularly care about what department you're in (unless you are in a "cost recovery" program). Do the research to make sure you will qualify for a waiver position before accepting any graduate school offer.
cons:
As stated above, you have to watch the tax situation as a graduate student employee. You should also know that some departments accept many more students than they have professional positions for (looking at you, library science). The library school had over 200 students in one class, and those were only the in-person students (non online). Compare that with maybe 100 library student positions, perhaps half of those with waivers, and consider the competition. 

Masters students and PhD students are treated very differently in some departments, and less so in others. For example, just to be accepted to the Classics MA program meant you were already qualified to teach basic Latin/Greek and Civilization type courses.

pros: There are many great people with bright minds working here. It is rare for you to be the smartest person in the room, and that is a great motivator to learn more.
cons: There are lots of smart people working here, but lots of educated idiots trying to manage them. Just because you have a PhD in something doesn't mean you are good at managing people or anything outside of your area of expertise. The HR system is totally disjointed and decentralized. A job description and pay grade in one department has no bearing on the same job description and pay grade in another department. People in Administration get paid a lot more than people on the Academic side, how is this possible when the main "business" is driven by Academics? It has all the hallmarks of a State run entity.  And, we have the totally outdated Civil Servant model for employees that basically creates a turf war for the State Universities Civil Service System (that's right SUCSS) to try to control employment vs the more modern Academic Professional employment system. Illinois is an "Employment at Will" state so why not ditch both SUCCS and Academic Professionals and hire and fire like real businesses? Getting a promotion or a raise is nearly impossible. The only way to accomplish this is to get another job offer. Looking below in this reviewing system I see benefits mentioned; we used to tell prospective employees that the low pay was offset by the great benefits but now our State legislators are trying to renege on our contracts and write new laws to strip us of legally contracted benefits. Ask for a fair wage if you work here because you can't count on the benefits.

review_title: State Budget Problems Effect University Employees

Positions remain unfilled and others must pick up the slack to complete this necessary work.  Health insurance and retirement benefits may be changing (for the worse) due to state budget.

job_title: Graduate Research Student in Champaign, IL
pros: As a graduate student going for a PhD in Biochemistry I was paid $25k a year to go to school and I didn't have to pay the $27k tuition. Full health insurance also only costed $340 a semester. Pretty sweet deal.
cons: Depending on your professor, you would have to work very difficult hours on many projects. I was on 5 projects and teaching 40 students a lab class. The experience was rewarding but I got worn down to the point where I had to leave for my mental and physical health.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Urbana, IL

Champaign-Urbana is a great place to live - there is more to do here than you think and the housing is affordable.
cons: If you want to stay in the community after grad school there are not a lot of science/biotech jobs available, especially outside of the university.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Urbana, IL

cons: The town might be small for some. The winter weather can be difficult. The campus is so large that sometimes you can get lost amongst other students.

pros:

cons: There is quite a workload from time to time. That's something that shouldn't be underestimated. Also, I wish it was easier for students in Electrical Engineering to get into computer science courses.

review_title: Good to have a part time job in the Dining Hall
pros: The time is flexible and the job is not too hard. You just need to do your part and the supervisors are happy to teach you how to do your jobs. You can learn how the process of a school dining hall, and you can also make friends with people who also work here.
cons: Depend on who your supervisor is, sometimes you need to pretend you are very busy.

review_title: There is a crisis of management in Student Affairs at the University.
pros: The benefits are terrific, and working with students can be rewarding.
cons: The University is so large it is full of silos and people reinventing the wheel.  It takes so long to get anything done because of the bureaucracy.

pros: Accessible as a student. most of the time it's pretty relaxed. Usually no mess ups on payday which is important to college students
cons: Honestly, sometimes your boss takes the job too seriously depending on the nature. At the dining hall, they were entirely too much. All you have to do is stack cups lol

pros: Worked in the Technology Services department as a consultant while I was a full-time student and they were very accommodating to my schedule
cons: There were no downsides to this job since there was such a great atmosphere and the management understood that we were all students and had dynamic schedules

pros: It is pretty stable. Students are mostly understanding, and we had small teaching groups to support each other's teaching.
cons: It is a lot of work, five days a week, so it consumes a lot of time. Plus, we didn't have online grading system, so a bigger class is really taxing.

review_title: World class education and great research opportunities.
pros: Great people, world class research, and great networking opportunities made this job a great experience. The sheer amount of knowledge the faculty possesses is amazing and the research is one of a kind.
cons: Lack of overtime and no benefits. This job was better for future opportunities through networking or for getting into a graduate program. The undergraduate workers were sometimes difficult to deal with, but that is a matter of experience.

review_title: Overall I have had a very good experience.
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Urbana, IL
pros: In general I have found the faculty to be very supportive, both in classes and research.  The research resources at the university are fantastic.  The campus life is good, as well.
cons: Overall the compensation is low, but is about average for a graduate research assistantship.  Can end up spending significant portions of time on your own, so may not be the best position for a 'social butterfly'.

review_title: Very good experience being my first official job.
pros: The positive is that it works well to having a job after you graduate to still have an income along with experience.
cons: Depending on degree the pay is not the best. It is entry level position and entry level pay. Great for starting but couldn't see long term.

review_title: The University of Illinois is an encouraging, supportive environment, but it is Illinois.
pros: World Class University, large metro opportunities in a Midwest town setting, good benefits, excellent supervisor
cons: It IS the State of Illinois, it would be much better if Illinois placed higher on many important national "lists".

review_title: Overall, it's an excellent place for research scientists
job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in Urbana, IL
pros: It's a good grad school with excellent resources, well, you have to be sure about grad school is what you want and hopefully, you are lucky with a promising lab and productive project.
cons: Location, hard for travel, hard for get a job (geologically speaking, it's technical hub of NOTHING) around chambana.
